titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Bourne Family Papers
titlestmt.author: by Afua Ferdnance

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 05:58

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Bourne Family Papers consists of materials that document the lives of abolitionist, minister and newspaper editor George Bourne, his wife Mary Oland Stibbs Bourne and their descendants. The majority of materials in the collection document the professional careers of George Bourne and his son Theodore Bourne. George Bourne's papers include an Anti-Slavery Lecture of 1837 along with other religious writings. Theodore Bourne's papers chiefly relate to African American repatriation organizations such as the African Christian Civilization Society. Correspondence between the Bourne and Stibbs family in England and the United States document George and Mary Bourne's new life as they settled throughout the United States. Poems written by members of the Bourne Family and others such as abolitionists James Montgomery, Helen Maria Williams and John Greenleaf Whitter are also included.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from William Reese Co. (Swann Galleries sale, 2014 March 27, lot 41) on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Bourne Family Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Bourne Family Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: George Bourne was born on June 13, 1780 in Westbury, Wiltshire, England. In 1804, he married Mary Oland Stibbs (1780-1851), and they moved from England to the United States where they had ten children. George Bourne and his family moved frequently, settling in New York, Maryland, Virginia, and Pennsylvania. In 1810, George Bourne moved his family to New Glasgow, Virginia and became a Presbyterian minister. It was in Virginia that Bourne witnessed the American slavery system and as a result, became one of the founders of the American Anti-Slavery Society. Bourne wrote many anti-slavery articles as the editor for the Christian Intelligencer and the Baltimore Daily Gazette. George Bourne wrote The Book and Slavery Irreconcilable (1816) and delivered The Anti-Slavery Lecture of 1837 in Newburyport, Massachusetts. George Bourne died in New York on November 20, 1845. George Bourne's sons Theodore Bourne (1822-1910), William Oland Bourne (1819-1901) and Rowland Hill Bourne (1812-1886) held similar anti-slavery and religious interests. William Oland Bourne and Rowland Hill Bourne became ministers while Theodore Bourne participated in African American repatriation movements such as the African Christian Civilization Society, which sought to encourage African American immigration to West Africa including Liberia and present day Nigeria.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Bourne Family Papers consist of materials that document the lives of abolitionist, minister and newspaper editor George Bourne, his wife Mary Oland Stibbs Bourne and their descendants. The majority of materials in the collection document the professional careers of George Bourne and his son Theodore Bourne. George Bourne's papers include an Anti-Slavery Lecture of 1837 as well as other religious writings. Theodore Bourne's papers relate to African American repatriation organizations such as the African Christian Civilization Society founded by Henry Highland Garnet. Correspondence between the Bourne and Stibbs family in England and the United States documents George and Mary Bourne's new life as they settled throughout the United States. Poems written by members of the Bourne Family such as Theodore Bourne and his brother William Oland Bourne are found in the collection. Other writings from abolitionists James Montgomery, Helen Maria Williams and John Greeenleaf Whitter are also included.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence (1793-1919). II. Professional Papers (1793-1910). III. Personal Papers (1793-1910).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into two subseries: Family Correspondence and General Correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Family Correspondence includes letters exchanged between the Bourne and Stibbs family in England as well as in the United States. Mary Oland Stibbs Bourne corresponded frequently with her family in England about family life in the United States. She also corresponded with her children as they grew into adults.

General Correspondence includes letters from friends and colleagues of the Bourne Family. George Bourne wrote frequently to other ministers and abolitionists such as Dan Bryan regarding anti-slavery movements. Correspondence to Theodore Bourne chiefly comes from members of the African Christian Civilization Society and the African Aid Society. Abolitionist and physician Martin R. Delany, teacher Robert Campbell and Lord Alfred Churchill of England corresponded with Theodore Bourne with regard to African American repatriation.

did.unittitle: Letters received by Mary Oland Stibbs Bourne
Letters received by Mary Bourne Nesbit
Letters received by Thomas Oland Stibbs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two photographs are included with this letter. One photograph is of Thomas Roberts and his brother of Monrovia, Liberia (1886) and another of school children (undated).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Professional Papers documents the careers of the Bourne family. Religious texts written by George Bourne for the Christian Intelligencer, as well as anti-slavery texts such as The Anti-Slavery Lecture of 1837 , are in this series. Theodore Bourne's writings include "A Biographical Sketch of George Bourne" along with an account of George Bourne and his interaction with Thomas Paine. Theodore Bourne's papers from his work as secretary of the African Christian Civilization Society is well documented. Publications written by members of the African Christian Civilization Society such as Quaker Benjamin Coates and Jehu T. Dimey are also included. Maps illustrating nineteenth-century African nations are found within the series. Other papers from organizations such as the African Aid Society, Freedmen's Mission Aid Society, International Migration Society and the American Missionary Association are also included in the series. Material related to members of the Bourne family including William Oland Bourne can also be found. Writings by others include clippings by John Greenleaf Whittier, original poems by James Montgomery and Samuel W. Seton as well as writings by Helen Maria Williams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copy of a small portrait of James Montgomery included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Personal Papers includes genealogical records, illustrations, photographs and objects. Two photographs, one of George M. Bourne and one of his driver can be found within the series. Objects include rosary beads, spectacles and spectacle cases.
